page.title: 10WARRINGTON TOWN HALL
page.content: In 1847, the town was granted the status of a municipal corporation and a council was elected, comprising a Mayor, nine aldermen and twenty-seven councillors. The original Town Hall building now stands in Golden Square but, by 1870, this had become inadequate. Fortunately Bank Hall, home of Lord Winmarleigh, was bought with the aid of Lord Winmarleigh himself and George Crossfield. The Hall had been built in 1750 by James Gibb for the Patten family, later to become Wilson-Patten then Lord Winmarleigh. At the front of the Town Hall are some magnificent cast-iron gates 25 feet high and 54 feet across given to the town in 1893 by Frederick Monks and have recently been re-gilded and fully restored.
